history.content:
Good news for you, I think the important aspects of 127 really only covers 3 weeks of the semester. Try to study/ watch lectures/ read the tb/ wikipedia:

- linear programs (LP)

- how LP can be generalized to QP/QCQP/SOCP/SDP (optional)

- how they all don't matter because the only requirement is convexity

- Lagrangian Duality (Strong and Weak) (most important i think. understand how it works, what conditions must be met etc.)

That is really all the new material from 127. Everything else is linalg from 16ab. That being said, a lot of insight 127 gives you comes from the problem sets. They really allow you to apply the optimization and learn a few handy tricks. The tldr of the course is just an optimization problem is when you attach a min to an expression and it has to satisfy some constraints, and it can be solved efficiently by an algorithm if the expression and the constraints are convex.

Hello, I was planning on taking 189 and 127 concurrently this semester, but alas, they have a time conflict, so I'll probably only be taking 189. Can anyone who took 189 last fall provide a list of topics from 127 that are useful to study before going into 189? I'm a bit nervous since I know the Fall version of 189 usually relies on 127 concepts a little more, but I don't have time to self-study the entire course.
history.subject: 127 Concepts to prep for 189
